subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] regional accents
msgSnippet: Good points there. Thanks Nathan. I suppose the main point here is that writing is communication within a group of people and in order to do it successfully an
messageBody:
Good points there. Thanks Nathan. I suppose the main point here is that writing is communication within a group of people and in order to do it successfully an agreed method for mutual understanding is necessary and has to be worked out.

I can't help but be fascinated by the way in which regular standardized spelling systems like we have in English actually mask the changes happening in the language. Something which Quickscript shines a light on. In a globalized world we are used to hearing so many accents, we don't give it any thought.

I was learning a few words of Russian for my job. I thought, "OK, Russian is spelt phonetically, I've mastered the alphabet and understand the sound associated with each letter, I can just learn to speak from book learning". Well how wrong I was. Audio recordings were critical for learning the Moscow pronunciation and seeing how the spelling differed from true speech. Not so phonetic any more.

Thanks for the blog link. I'll see if I can get a blog to work in Quickscipt too.


On Wednesday, 13 November 2013 5:42 AM, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:

On Nov 11, 2013, at 8:02 PM, pgabhart@... wrote:

>
>
> I agree with you.  What is wrong with hearing a writer's accent come through in his writing?  I cannot believe it causes that much trouble in reading.  After all, we don't insist that everyone eschew their regional accents in their speech, so why is it any more logical to insist that all English writers be forced to spell according to an arbitrary standard?

When speaking, you can usually ask the person you're listening to for clarification as they're right there in front of you. If I want to ask H. P. Lovecraft (1830–1937) how to pronounce "wgah'nagl", I'm going to have to put down my book and buy — or design — a *very* specialized ouija board. Having to pause my reading and go "hmmm, what word does the author really mean?" is a huge speed impediment, if nothing else.

If everyone spells the same way, things are easier and faster to read, since you don't have to try to imagine how to correct for one particular speaker's idiosyncrasies. "Everyone learn how to read and write spellings based on how an RP speaker would pronounce things in 1960, and add rhoticity" is an easier rule to follow than "everyone learn how to write their own dialect and read everyone else's". Similarly, "everyone learn English", "everyone learn French", and "everyone learn Latin" have generally been more popular than "every European learn every other European language".

John Cowan already demonstrated how bad the mutual-intelligibility problem can get in <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/message/2423>:

> To make things worse, writing in QS exactly as we speak will cause severe
> problems with intelligibility across accent boundaries. If Alice from
> London writes <Fife, Eat, Fife>, North Americans will not recognize this
> as "thief". If Bob from Philadelphia writes <Deed, Ah, Loll>, people
> from outside North America will not recognize this as "doll". If Charlie
> from Edinburgh writes <Tut, Ed, Roar, Mime>, only people from Scotland
> and Ireland and those who know traditional orthography will recognize
> this as "term". If David from New Zealand writes <Sis, Ado, Ax>, only
> his countrymen will recognize this as "six"; all other anglophones will
> take it to be "sucks". ("Australia sux, New Zealand nil.") Likewise,
> Eve from California will bewilder most of us with her <Kick, Eat,
> Inkling>, as the rest of us say <Kick, If, Inkling> for "king".
>
> When Frank, a policeman from Chicago, writes that he searched every <Bob,
> Loll, Ash, Kick> for guns, the rest of us may think this is racial
> profiling, but Frank merely meant that he searched every "block".
> Greta from Newcastle-on-Tyne may write <Kick, Wool, Deed>, and people
> outside the North of England will think she is writing "could" rather than
> "cud". When Henry from Cardiff, Princess Imogen of Britain, James from
> Melbourne, and Kayla from Indianapolis write <Deed, If, Win-win>, <Deed,
> Yo-yo, Ooze>, <Judge, Ooze>, and <Deed, Ooze> respectively, it will take
> them some work to figure out that all these spellings represent the word
> "dew". I could go on for a *very* long time.

Because of this, I'm OK with using just .Ah (and ignoring .Awe and .Ox) in notes to myself, but when I'm writing for other people (<http://www.frogorbits.com/blog/>), I take pains to get the spelling right. It's unreasonable to expect other people to have to try and divine my idiolect.

------------------------------------
